Cause of Incident: A train bridge over the Marys River in Corvallis collapsed because of structural failure, sending one train car filled with agricultural materials into the river.
Damage Description: A “structural failure” caused the Jan. 4 bridge collapse in Corvallis that sent two Portland & Western rail cars into the river, including one that was partially submerged in the river and one that was almost entirely submerged in the water.
Estimated Repair Cost: The Portland & Western Railroad bridge over Mary's River is undergoing repairs, with an estimated cost of around $1 million.
Source / Reference: Marys River train bridge in Corvallis collapses, one train car falls into river - oregonlive.com  https://www.chronline.com/stories/oregon-train-bridge-collapse-sent-150000-pounds-of-fertilizer-into-river,373467

Cause of Incident: The damage was caused by a truck that inexplicably had its bed raised high enough to make contact with the underside of the bridge as the vehicle passed below it
Damage Description: Significant damage that required full overpass closure and extensive repairs.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed for a weekend

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The approach remained centered on maintaining vigilant routine inspections and ensuring rapid containment if future incidents occur.
Cause of Incident: Loose barge
Damage Description: A barge got loose on the swollen Little Kanawha River and floated downstream. The vessel, loaded with what appeared to be sand or gravel, drifted downstream and struck the bridge piling of a railroad trestle at Parkersburg.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The collision triggered swift safety inspections and an ongoing investigation. As of now, there is no evidence of permanent infrastructure upgrades (like fender systems or mooring improvements) at the Melville railroad bridge.
Cause of Incident: The cause is still being investigated.
Damage Description: A railroad bridge in St. Landry Parish was struck by a tugboat in the Atchafalaya River. Officials said the tugboat hit the railroad trestle in Melville while moving barges down the river. While there have been no immediate reports of injuries, officials have said there is significant damage to the barge it.

Cause of Incident: Miscalculation
Damage Description: A tractor-trailer  hit a concrete overpass at Upper River Road while transporting an excavator. Inspection found damage to the concrete on all six bridge girders – the long, horizontal beams that support the bridge deck. However, in all but one girder, the steel rebar appeared intact
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary lane closure
Estimated Repair Cost: ALDOT negotiated for the repair to be performed as a $358,185 supplement to a pre-existing $16.1 million contract with Rogers Group for the ongoing resurfacing of I-65 in Morgan County.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Regarding future prevention, no new barrier systems (like fenders or bollards) or operational changes have been publicly announced since this incident. However, the pre-existing upgrades—notably the underwater radar system installed in 2013—remain a key measure for improving navigation safety.
Cause of Incident: High water flow
Damage Description: A tugboat was pushing 22 barges down the river when two broke off and crashed into the old Highway 80 bridge.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The new bridge is designed to be higher and feature wider spaces between its support columns. This eliminates the need for a central lift span present in the current bridge, providing a wider and safer passage for barges navigating the Columbia River underneath. Ahead of the replacement, coating condition assessments and engineering monitoring of the existing structure are planned from July–September 2025.
Cause of Incident: High wind gusts reportedly caused barge wires to part, necessitating a maneuver downstream to resecure the tow.
Damage Description: A Shaver Transportation barge had made contact with the inside face of the northernmost lift span pier of the Hood River-White Salmon Interstate Bridge. the impact caused only superficial surface marring to the bridge pier and no structural damage.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary closure

Bridge Name: Alaska Railroad Bridge over Talkeetna River
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Railroad staff had initiated a change order to widen the walkway on May 20, just a day prior to the collision
Damage Description: An ATV trespassed onto railroad bridge and was struck by a passing Alaska Railroad train, no reported damage to bridge structure.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Immediate reactions prioritized safety and emergency response. Investigations are ongoing but yet to yield recommendations.Preventive steps remain speculative—no concrete improvements have been announced.
Cause of Incident: The ship did not maneuver as planned, and travelled backwards under the nearby Brooklyn Bridge, crashing into the span.
Damage Description: The Mexican Navy ship Cuauhtémoc struck the Brooklyn Bridge while departing New York City. The ship's masts collided with the underside of the bridge, at around the height of her topgallant sails, causing the loss of her topmasts and resulting in two deaths and multiple injuries of people aboard the vessel. The Brooklyn Bridge sustained no major structural damage.
Duration of Service Disruption: All lanes on both sides were briefly closed and reopened soon after the incdient.

Cause of Incident: The cause is still being investigated.
Damage Description: A portion of Interstate 27 near Tulia remains closed after a crane being hauled on a tractor-trailer crashed into an overpass, causing considerable damage Tuesday morning in Swisher County. The arm of a crane being hauled on a tractor-trailer collided with the FM 928 overpass, according to the Texas Department of Public Safety.
Duration of Service Disruption: The overpass will be closed for the foreseeable future as damage is evaluated and repairs are made.
Source / Reference: Part of I-27 closed in Texas Panhandle after crane, overpass crash

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Ongoing investigations may lead to future safeguards—but as of now, no concrete preventive measures (like structural installations or new regulations) have been publicly announced.
Cause of Incident: The cause is still being investigated.
Damage Description: A barge broke loose from the others and struck the Coffeeville River Bridge. The extent of the damage to the structure was not clear.
Duration of Service Disruption: Drivers were rerouted. The roadway has been reopened after the bridge was inspected and deemed safe.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The old bridge is about to be replaced. The new bridge will have modernized draw controls, improved structural integrity and wider structure and shoulders.
Cause of Incident: Operator Lost directional control
Damage Description: A 56-foot recreational boat crashed into the Rumson-Sea Bright Bridge.

Cause of Incident: The FM 1431 bridge over Cow Creek, built in 1960 to connect Lago Vista and Marble Falls, was ripped apart by floodwaters.
Damage Description: Flash floods severely damaged a bridge at Big Sandy Road and Round Mountain Road — the only way in and out of the neighborhood. Concrete slabs tossed into the creek bed like dominos.
Duration of Service Disruption: Travis County is working with the state to craft a temporary crossing into the Sandy Creek community

Cause of Incident: Catastrophic flooding washed away the Burnet County bridge.
Damage Description: Flooding along the San Gabriel River Saturday morning swept away a historic bridge in Burnet County. the bridge once stood, only support piers remain. A section of the wooden bridge deck sat on top of tree branches along the riverbank. But the iron bridge structure that once spanned the river could not be seen nearby.

Cause of Incident: Ice fog
Damage Description: Dense ice fog drastically reduced visibility (~one vehicle length); a single vehicle spun on icy bridge, triggering a chain-reaction involving 37 vehicles.  Multiple vehicles involved; bridge deck had no reported structural damage, but roadway closures and significant traffic disruption occurred; injuries to ~13 people
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary road closure

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Temporary barrier repairs remain in place, but no permanent upgrades (e.g. fender systems, additional bollards, or navigational aids) have been publicly announced. Ongoing investigations by the Coast Guard and law enforcement may influence future safety measures, but as of now, no further public action has been disclosed.
Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: The vessel, Lady Anna, ran aground while attempting to dock at Pier 16, and made contact with the Nuuanu Stream Bridge causing damage to one section of the fence and bridge railing

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The new bridge will include robust fendering systems and protective dolphins  to absorb and redirect ship impacts. A wider and taller clearance span for maritime traffic, reducing the chance of ship-bridge collisions. Expected to include real-time structural health monitoring systems to detect stress, vibrations, and possible early damage. modern engineering codes with redundant load paths.
Cause of Incident: Loss of control at the crew's end that were operating the vessel.
Damage Description: A large container ship, MV Dali, lost power and struck a support pier, causing the complete collapse of the bridge. Six men – all of them workers performing routine road maintenance – lost their lives
Duration of Service Disruption: The collapse blocked most shipping to and from the Port of Baltimore for 11 weeks.
Estimated Repair Cost: Maryland officials have said they plan to replace the bridge by fall 2028 at an estimated cost of $1.7 billion to $1.9 billion.
Source / Reference: Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse - Wikipedia
Notes: Maryland Governor Wes Moore called the event a "global crisis" that had affected more than 8,000 jobs.The economic impact of the closure of the waterway has been estimated at $15 million per day.
column14: In 1980, a ship roughly one-third the size of Dali struck and lightly damaged one of the bridge's piers.[38][39][40] After the bridge collapsed in 2024, anonymous former agency officials told The Washington Post that the Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) did not consider studying the possibility of a collision with a larger ship, and instead spent decades studying how terrorists might attack the bridge after the September 11 attacks or inspecting for structural flaws similar to those that caused the I-35W Mississippi River bridge collapse in 2007.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: None reported—no structural changes or added navigational protections announced.
Cause of Incident: The cause of the collision is unknown.
Damage Description: The Oklahoma State Patrol said that it closed a highway south of Sallisaw after a barge struck a bridge over Arkansas River.
Duration of Service Disruption: The highway was closed for few hours.
Source / Reference: Arkansas River bridge struck by barge on Saturday - Oklahoma Energy Today

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: There’s no indication that additional fender systems, upgraded bollards, or structural enhancements were installed at the Sewickley Bridge or nearby mooring areas following the incident.
Cause of Incident: Barges broke loose from their moorings.
Damage Description: 26 barges broke loose from their moorings. The barges, primarily carrying non-hazardous dry cargo like coal, drifted down the rain-swollen river. Several became stuck at the Emsworth Lock and Dam, and at least one struck a pillar of the Sewickley Bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: The Sewickley Bridge was temporarily closed for inspections after being hit by a barge. It was reopened after inspections deemed it safe.
Source / Reference: Barges break loose on Ohio River in Pittsburgh, damaging a marina and striking a bridge | AP News

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: INDOT continues with its standard bridge safety protocol, which includes periodic inspections and maintenance—but not specifically enhanced protections against waterborne vessel impacts
Damage Description: a minor barge hit: non-structurally detrimental damage was visible

Cause of Incident: The I-95 bridge in Norwalk, Connecticut, collapsed due to a fiery crash involving a tanker truck carrying gasoline.
Damage Description: A motor vehicle collision involving a gas tanker caused a fire on I-95 in Norwalk, Connecticut. The bridge was heavily damaged by flames on Thursday morning after a three-vehicle collision caused a gas/petroleum tanker to burst into flames under the overpass.
Duration of Service Disruption: Within 80 hours, the damaged overpass was removed, and all lanes reopened, relieving the congestion but leaving Norwalk residents without a vital connection to the busy Route 1 corridor with no bridge over that section of highway.
Estimated Repair Cost: I-95 Norwalk bridge repair estimated to cost $20 million

Bridge Name: State Road 19 bridge on Lake Harris
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: FDOT’s ongoing SR 19 bridge replacement project—which includes upgraded approaches, lighting, signage, and structural reinforcements—has been accelerated. It integrates additional safety buffers specifically to mitigate future vessel impacts.
Damage Description: A 19-foot aluminum boat with two men aboard struck the bridge

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: No public announcements have indicated installation of new navigational safeguards like fenders, dolphins, upgraded bollards, or traffic control systems at the bridge site.
Cause of Incident: Barge became loose from the tow
Damage Description: A barge struck the north side of the bridge shortly, leaving the swing gate bridge stuck in the open position.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed for few hours

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: There's no available record of follow-up actions or long-term preventive measures taken afterward.
Cause of Incident: Unspecified
Damage Description: A barge pushed by a tug boat hit one of the fenders protecting the pilings on J. Wilton Graves Bridge on U.S. Highway 278 the ship struck and collapsed the fender of the bridge section

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Replacement bridge is on the plans. The new design aims to eliminate outdated truss spans and improve overall structural resilience.
Cause of Incident: Tugboat coupling failed; a 321-ft fuel barge drifted and struck a bridge pier
Damage Description: Bridge pier damaged, protection structure collapsed, debris in water
Duration of Service Disruption: Road access disrupted for days; waterway closed within 6.5 miles for cleanup
Notes: Only road access to Pelican Island; affected Texas A&M Galveston students and staff

Bridge Name: Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad Bridge
Cause of Incident: The bridge collapse was a direct result of the extreme flooding in the area, with the Big Sioux River reaching record high levels.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Cause of Incident: High speed and DUI
Damage Description: The center console boat was traveling at a “high rate of speed” around 2 a.m. on Monday when it crashed into the South Pine Channel Bridge

Cause of Incident: Mechanical failure
Damage Description: Northport bridge closed after vehicle crash. The driver slammed into the concrete guardrails. The hit was so powerful it sent chunks of concrete down below to the railroad tracks.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and bridge owner to conduct a quantitative risk evaluation—measuring factors like vessel traffic, pier resistance, and protective measures—and implement mitigation plans if needed.
Cause of Incident: Strong current
Damage Description: Read more at: https://www.islandpacket.com/news/local/crime/article288431719.html#storylink=cpy

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Coast Guard and FDOT jointly re-evaluated barge placement zones near bridge foundations to minimize risk of vessel impacts. Verified fendering and pier protection systems.
Cause of Incident: Boat operator driving under influence
Damage Description: A 20-foot vessel with two occupants collided with a barge, and an occupant fell into the water.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Damage Description: a boat struck a stanchion left behind in Boston Harbor from a bridge that was demolished nearly a decade ago

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The bridge has been officially limited to 15‑ton vehicle weights, restricting emergency vehicles like fire trucks and ambulances. Initial design phase is underway (fall 2024), and full replacement is scheduled for sometime after 2030.
Cause of Incident: A commercial fishing boat lost power and crashed into the bridge
Damage Description: A large fishing boat lost power and hit the Middle Thorofare Bridge
Duration of Service Disruption: Overnight closure

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Emergency measures were immediate and effective.  Monitoring for pollution and potential hazards was conducted. No evidence of longer-term preventive initiatives like infrastructure improvements, navigational restrictions, or procedural safeguards has been announced.
Damage Description: A boat crashed into part of the remains of the old Long Island Bridge in Boston Harbor.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Official follow-up has been limited to standard inspections ensuring the bridge’s structural integrity. There are no known updates from Cape May County, the New Jersey DOT, or Coast Guard regarding changes to navigation procedures or added protective infrastructure at the bridge site.
Cause of Incident: 90-foot fishing boat, the Jersey Cape, collided with the bridge after losing power
Damage Description: This mechanical failure rendered the bridge inoperable, forcing its closure to vehicular, pedestrian, and bike traffic.
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge was closed temporarily for repairs.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Any damaged fenders or pier bumpers were repaired or replaced to ensure structural protection before the broader rehabilitation work commenced.
Cause of Incident: May be mechanical or the high current.
Damage Description: The 94-metre Feadship, delivered in 2021, was navigating the waterways when it wedged itself precariously close to the bridge, leaving onlookers both shocked and amused. Fortunately, the incident did not result in major damage to either the yacht or the bridge.

Cause of Incident: Vehicle collision
Damage Description: A semi hauling double trailers merged, leading to a rear-end collision; one vehicle subsequently caught fire atop an overpass (no structural bridge damage reported)
Duration of Service Disruption: Road closure ~3 hours

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Awareness was raised regarding the bridge’s precise clearance limits, especially for vessels with lengthy equipment.
Damage Description: A shrimp boat collision with the Matanzas Pass Bridge in Fort Myers, Florida, temporarily disrupted traffic and marine activity on Monday morning.
Duration of Service Disruption: Bridge closure for few hours.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Fender system replacement completed. Infrastructure maintenance focus strengthened.
Cause of Incident: Incorrect Lineup Leads to Tugboat Damaging Hylebos Bridge Fender System
Damage Description: The deteriorated fender system protecting the Hylebos Bridge in Tacoma, Washington, was damaged beyond repair last October after being struck by a tugboat assisting an articulated tug and barge, or ATB.
Estimated Repair Cost: The damaged south fender was replaced with a steel fender at an estimated cost of $2.43 million.

Cause of Incident: The bridge was destroyed by the flooding of Hurricane Helene.
Damage Description: The flood waters washed away the west riverbank, leaving no structure connecting the bridge to the land on the other side.
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge is closed to the public due to the damage and safety concerns.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Cause of Incident: Excessive boat speed, less visibility
Damage Description: A boat crashed into a piling near the Card Sound Road Bridge in Key Largo

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Actions taken were limited to routine structural inspections and continued monitoring of bridge integrity.
Cause of Incident: Flood swollen river
Damage Description: The bridge, which carries Hanapepe Road over the river, was struck by an empty, privately owned cargo container. The bridge wasn't damaged.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary closure until investigated

Cause of Incident: Driving while disqualified, failure to stop, and overheight without a permit.
Damage Description: The bridge was struck and damaged by an over-height load, including a broken steel support beam. Debris also fell onto I-75, striking vehicles and causing injuries.
Duration of Service Disruption: The impact led to the closure of the bridge for repairs and traffic restrictions on I-75.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Safety reminders were issued through FWC channels and local media, emphasizing: Maintaining safe speed near bridge piers, Wearing life jackets and monitoring vessel conditions.
Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: A boat traveling in the Caloosahatchee River struck the Cape Coral Bridge. After hitting the bridge, the vessel took on water and sank.

Cause of Incident: Fatigued driver
Damage Description: Fatigued pickup-truck driver drifted into bike lane, striking a concrete barrier and group of bicyclists on the bridge

Bridge Name: Hillcrest Drive over Minnesota Drive Overpass
Cause of Incident: Miscalculation of the overhead bridge span
Damage Description: A commercial vehicle carrying heavy equipment was traveling northbound on Minnesota Drive when it collided with Hillcrest Drive overpass. Two steel girders beneath the bridge were damaged; inspection team reviewed condition before reopening; sidewalk shoulder closed temporarily.
Duration of Service Disruption: A lengthy closure for a day

Damage Description: Shoal Creek Bridge in rural Lauderdale County had to be closed after a barge was found resting against its supports when while water was high and running quickly
Duration of Service Disruption: Temprary closure

Bridge Name: Railroad bridge on the Black Warrior River
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Not specified
Cause of Incident: May be mechanical or human error.
Damage Description: A towing vessel collided with a railroad bridge on the Black Warrior River in Alabama. No damage was found on the vessel or bridge

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: No public record indicates implementation of permanent structural protections (e.g. fenders, dolphins, bollards) at the impacted bridge or nearby mooring areas.
Cause of Incident: High current
Damage Description: More than two dozen river barges broke loose from their moorings and floated down the Ohio River, damaging a marina and striking a bridge
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary closure until investigated

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: There is currently no public indication of structural changes (e.g., fender systems or dolphins) at that bridge as a result. Maritime operators are encouraged to implement BRM-type crew training, which reinforces active monitoring, error-checking, and safety culture.
Cause of Incident: The captain, intending to guide the tow via the western channel under the bridge, admitted that he was not attentive enough during the approach, which led to the tow being misplaced.
Damage Description: The incident resulted in one barge sinking and damage to two others

Bridge Name: U.S. 191 Overpass over Interstate 10 – Willcox area

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: This incident led to significant enhancements in structural protection (fenders/dolphins), acknowledged gaps in operator knowledge (prompting recommendations), and improvements in rehabilitation efforts.
Damage Description: A runaway barge hits Eads bridge. No damage was observed on the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Service was haulted till the time the bridge was investigated for its safety.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: No physical structural upgrades (e.g., fenders or span redesign) were recommended or undertaken following the incident.
Cause of Incident: Errors by the captains
Damage Description: A captain and barge company managers not identifying the crane they were towing was too high to pass under the Mackinac Bridge near Mackinaw City, Michigan led to the crane hitting the bridge.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Actions remained focused on post-collision inspection and standard safety monitoring.
Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: A barge hit a bridge in the Florida Keys bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: No damage

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Increased water patrols, Targeted BUI (Boating Under the Influence) enforcement.
Cause of Incident: Driving under influence
Damage Description: Lewis Newsom, 48, of Groves, was driving the boat shortly before sunset Friday when it struck the bridge on Boondocks Road at the North Fork of Taylor Bayou.

Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: A semi-truck crashed into a bridge pillar supporting U.S. 191 over I‑10, resulting in a fatality and substantial structural damage.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Install or reinforce impact-absorbing fender systems around bridge piers to protect the structure from collisions and reduce damage to vessels.
Cause of Incident: Loss of situational awareness under low-light conditions
Damage Description: A 52-foot Viking Sky Bridge is shown after colliding with the Townsend’s Inlet Bridge causing it to sink in the Townsend’s Inlet

Cause of Incident: Driver's failure to slow down on an exit ramp, leading to the truck overturning and igniting.
Damage Description: A tanker truck carrying gasoline caught fire beneath the overpass that carries Interstate 95. The extreme heat caused the northbound lanes to collapse and damaged the southbound lanes, closing roughly nine miles (14 km) of both directions of I-95, between the Betsy Ross Bridge/Aramingo Avenue (exit 26) and PA 63/Woodhaven Road (exit 35).
Duration of Service Disruption: The swift construction of a temporary roadway enabled traffic to resume on June 23, less than two weeks after the fire.
Estimated Repair Cost: The repair cost for the I-95 bridge in Philadelphia, PA, following the June 2023 collapse, is estimated to be between $25 million and $30 million.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Safety efforts appear to have focused on immediate inspection and monitoring, with no indication of long-term upgrades tied to this event.
Cause of Incident: Engine trouble, causing the boat to lose power.
Damage Description: A boat crashed into Old Manns Harbor Bridge. The momentum and the current then pushed the boat into the bridge and caused the vessel’s flying bridge to collapse onto two people who were on board.

Cause of Incident: The cause of the collapse is under investigation, but some experts have suggested that repeated years of heavy river flows may have eroded the river bottom and weakened the bridge structure.
Damage Description: A bridge that crosses the Yellowstone River collapsed, causing several cars of a freight train carrying hazardous materials to fall into the water below. The incident resulted in environmental concerns and internet service disruptions in the state.The derailment caused various environmental concerns and disrupted transportation and internet services.
Duration of Service Disruption: 28-day Outage: This means train service was officially restored 28 days after the collapse.
Estimated Repair Cost: The cost to replace the Yellowstone River Bridge near Tower Junction in Yellowstone National Park is $118 million.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Damage Description: A single vessel struck the underside of a cement bridge at night. The operator fatally struck his head. The vehicle of injury: most likely head trauma—not a structural collapse.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The bridge's design and existing safety measures were deemed sufficient to handle the impact.  The NYCDOT continues to monitor the bridge's condition through regular inspections and maintains existing safety protocols to mitigate the risk of future collisions.
Cause of Incident: The collision was caused when the ship's master incorrectly calculated the crane's height as the barge moved north, leading to the crane contacting the underside of the bridge.
Damage Description: The Brooklyn Bridge survived a close call Wednesday morning after it was struck by a crane that damaged an I-beam underneath its iconic Gothic frame. The damage was not structural and “didn’t impact the integrity” of New York City’s oldest and most storied suspension bridge
Duration of Service Disruption: No closure

Bridge Name: State Highway 155 bridge over Lake Palestine
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Post-impact structural inspections were conducted, and the bridge was deemed safe with no repairs required.
Cause of Incident: Human error, equipment failure, weather conditions.
Damage Description: A small recreational boat hit a pillar on the State Highway 155 bridge. After the impact, the driver was ejected from the boat and killed.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Fender system replacement, Enhanced inspection protocols. The deteriorated wooden fender system, which failed to properly absorb impact, was completely replaced with a more robust steel fender system
Cause of Incident: Human error
Damage Description: The captain of an articulated tug and barge (ATB) failed to line up his vessel correctly while approaching the Hylebos Bridge in Tacoma, Washington, last year, causing an assisting tugboat to strike the bridge’s already deteriorated fender system.  The fender system required replacement

Bridge Name: Columbia River – Port Westward Beaver Dock
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: This incident focused entirely on human factors and onboard alert systems. There were no physical or structural bridge upgrades—such as fendering, bollards, or pier protections
Cause of Incident: Human error.
Damage Description: The towing vessel was pushing the loaded deck barge St. John up the Columbia River when the tow gradually moved to starboard out of the channel and struck the Port Westward Beaver Dock.

Cause of Incident: The Fern Hollow Bridge in Pittsburgh collapsed on January 28, 2022, due to extensive corrosion and section loss in the bridge's southwest leg, specifically within the transverse tie plate. This failure occurred because of clogged drains, which led to water and debris accumulation at the base of the legs, preventing the development of a protective rust layer and accelerating corrosion.
Damage Description: Under the road deck, the bridge carried a 16-inch (41 cm) natural gas pipeline, which severed in the collapse. Local residents were evacuated from their homes in response to reports of a "massive leak" and strong scent of natural gas. Officials shut down the gas lines in the area within a half hour of the collapse.
Duration of Service Disruption: The service disruption lasted roughly 11 months initially, followed by a shorter closure later for final completion.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: KYTC initiated emergency repair planning focused on steel railing and sidewalk support replacements.Repairs are being expedited using an existing maintenance contract to enable quick mobilization.Traffic control measures (barriers and lane management) were implemented to ensure safe repair work without full bridge closures.
Cause of Incident: Unspecified
Damage Description: The tow boat was downbound on the Ohio River attempting to make the turn to head upstream on the Mississippi River when the tow hit one of the right descending piers of the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Close to traffic for sometime.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Authorities opted for a complete replacement of the aging bridge. The new, modern structure significantly reduces the likelihood of vessel collisions by offering safer width, clearance, and structural resilience.
Cause of Incident: High current
Damage Description: Several barges broke free from their tow and struck the support pillars
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed for 3 hours

Damage Description: A pontoon boat filled with people was crushed as a drawbridge began to lift.

Cause of Incident: Rain storms caused the area to flood, washing out many roads and bridges.
Damage Description: A portion of the Point of Rocks Bridge broke, creating an impassable gap that forced the closure of US 89 for several weeks.
Duration of Service Disruption: Road closure for a week until temporarily repaired.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The primary response focused on search and rescue, vessel salvage, and bridge safety inspection.
Cause of Incident: Strong currents
Damage Description: A Jersey Shore charter boat that began to sink after hitting the Townsends Inlet Bridge linking Sea Isle City and Avalon Monday night has been towed to a marina and hauled from the water  for repairs.

Cause of Incident: The powerful storm, Hurricane Ian, which made landfall as a Category 4 hurricane on September 28th, washed away sections of the bridge and its approaches.
Damage Description: In September 2022, Hurricane Ian destroyed the causeway, cutting off Sanibel and Captiva Islands from the rest of the state of Florida and leaving residents stranded. Two portions of the ramp and a section of roadway that crossed an island in the middle of the causeway washed away in the storm. This damage effectively cut off Sanibel Island from the Florida mainland, making it inaccessible by car.
Duration of Service Disruption: Emergency repairs were completed in October 2022, restoring access to the island, but further restoration and strengthening of the causeway is ongoing.
Source / Reference: Florida’s $328M Sanibel Causeway restoration completed | Construction Dive

Cause of Incident: A temporary metal bridge in Puerto Rico, built in the wake of Hurricane Maria, was swept away in the rushing floodwaters of Hurricane Fiona.
Damage Description: Clattering metal was heard as the bridge comes loose and then flows downstream in one piece, whisked away by the current.

Cause of Incident: A bridge under construction in Clay County, Missouri, collapsed due to a faulty design of the temporary support structure (falsework) that was unable to support the weight of the wet concrete being poured.
Damage Description: Shady Grove Bridge, which crosses Carroll Creek at Northeast 148th Street near Kearney, collapsed while concrete pouring stage. The collapse sent tons of metal rebar, shattered wood forms, and wet concrete pouring into Carroll Creek.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: While the bridge was safely deemed operational with no repairs needed, no proactive upgrades or additional protective infrastructure were installed following this minor collision.
Cause of Incident: Speed of the towboats and potential errors by the captains.
Damage Description: A tug boat moving a tank, hit the bridge, the tank was rubbing the top of the bridge. The tugboat hit the bridge and it just kept on going. The bridge had minor damage.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: This case focused on bridge operating procedures and lighting improvements. No reports indicate structural modifications like enhanced fenders or dolphins were added to the bridge.
Cause of Incident: Poor communication between the bridge operator and vessel operator. Contributing to the accident was the absence of bridge span navigational lighting that would have provided the vessel operators with a visual indication of the bridge’s opening status.
Damage Description: An empty hopper barge, pushed by the towing vessel Robert Cenac, struck the CSX Railway Rigolets swing bridge.

Cause of Incident: This covered bridge over the Missisquoi River in Troy collapsed following a blaze that started when a snowmobile caught file while crossing.
Damage Description: Firefighters knocked down most of the blaze within 20 minutes, but the bridge’s beams gave out. The 121-year-old structure collapsed in the frozen river, a total loss.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The response prioritized swift safety checks and reopening of the bridge. However, there have been no confirmed long-term preventive actions—such as structural fortifications or navigation safeguards—reported since the incident.
Damage Description: Barge hits Mississippi River bridge in Dyer County
Duration of Service Disruption: The Tennessee Highway Patrol shut down both directions of I-155 in Dyer County closed at the Missouri-Tennessee state line around 10:30 a.m. It reopened around noon.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: This incident underscores that human oversight and ECS use—not physical infrastructure—were the primary failures.
Cause of Incident: The tow's pilot and captain "incorrectly identified" a caution area on the vessel’s electronic chart system (ECS) before pushing the tow up against a riverbank too close to a railroad track, leading to a train derailment near Galland, Iowa.
Damage Description: A barge struck a railroad bridge pier, causing track misalignment and temporary closure.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: PennDOT engineers monitored the bridge's bearings, which are critical components that support the bridge's structure. No movement was detected in these bearings, indicating that the bridge remained structurally sound.
Cause of Incident: Loose barge
Damage Description: One barge broke loose from a towboat and hit the span. Minor damage to the pier.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The NTSB recommended that marine operating companies develop and continuously evaluate severe weather plans to prepare for challenges associated with tropical storms and flooding.
Cause of Incident: Severe rainfall and flooding from Tropical Storm Imelda led to barges breaking away from their moorings and striking the Interstate 10 bridge
Damage Description: 11 barges broke free from a San Jacinto River barge fleeting area north of the I-10 bridge in Channelview during Tropical Storm Imelda, the fifth-wettest tropical cyclone on record in the continental United States. Six barges struck pier columns supporting the I-10 bridge

Cause of Incident: A collision pulling the bridge off its mooring was the main cause of the incident although the bridge received a 4, or "poor," rating after it was inspected in February.
Damage Description: A pedestrian bridge crashed down onto traffic on DC-295 in Northeast Washington, D.C., after a crash Wednesday. The bridge was on top of three lanes of the roadway. Fencing hung over three lanes of traffic in the opposite direction. Slabs of concrete and metal fencing were piled over a truck at one end of the bridge, which appeared to have completely detached from a staircase and platform.

Cause of Incident: An unusual crash in South Georgia shut down I-16, a major highway between Macon and Savannah, after the trailer of a dump truck struck an overhead bridge with enough force to shift the bridge deck by several feet.
Damage Description: The crash resulted in the closure of I-16 westbound and the Chatham Parkway overpass. Three beams on the bridge were significantly damaged and had to be removed. A pickup truck driver behind the excavator was injured by flying debris, and the driver of the tractor-trailer also sustained injuries.
Duration of Service Disruption: Since the accident, the four-lane bridge has been reduced to a single lane in each direction as drivers complain of traffic backups and increased travel times.
Estimated Repair Cost: The repair cost for the I-16 bridge on Chatham Parkway after an accident is estimated to be around $3.6 million for a full replacement. This cost is specifically for the replacement of the bridge damaged in the accident.

Cause of Incident: Flash flooding in Poudre Canyon caused significant damage, including the destruction of at least one bridge.
Damage Description: Roads, bridges, and culverts were washed out,

Cause of Incident: The truck, owned by Dove Transportation of Alabama, was hauling a water clarifying tank that was 9 inches higher than permitted and was traveling on an unapproved route, violating its permit.
Damage Description: The crash damaged the structural beams and a section of the bridge deck, forcing the closure of I-93 southbound and leading to significant traffic delays for commuters. The fascia beam on the inside of this bridge was completely flattened. It was nearly torn in half.
Duration of Service Disruption: Roosevelt Circle was operational, but with narrower lanes because crews removed eight to 10 feet of roadway during repairs.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Damage Description: 137-foot vessel struck the Sunrise Boulevard Bridge and became wedged under it

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Structural repairs focused on restoring the integrity of the impacted spans and supports.
Cause of Incident: Loss of control of the tow by the pilot at the helm of the towing vessel, likely due to impairment by factors such as fatigue or drug use.
Damage Description: A Louisiana barge tow struck and damaged a bridge's fender. When the tow struck the bridge, water, electrical and gas lines along the bridge ruptured, triggering alarms at the utility providers.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: In the aftermath, discussions have centered around enhancing bridge safety and preparedness for similar incidents.
Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: A Tennessee Valley Towing vessel was traveling northbound during the early morning hours when it struck the bridge, causing some of the barges to separate from the vessel. No damage to the bridge
Duration of Service Disruption: Closure for few hours.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Enhanced Communication Protocols, Increased Monitoring, Public Awareness Campaigns
Cause of Incident: Tropical Storm Isaias
Damage Description: The barges were displaced from their moorings near the Philadelphia Museum of Art and floated down the river, colliding with the north side of the Vine Street Expressway Bridge. The only thing they noticed was a bent stiffener bracket, which is not threatening the structure's integrity.
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge was closed to traffic and SEPTA service

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Increased Inspection Frequency
Cause of Incident: Windy conditions pushed a tow of six empty barges into the left descending main pier of the bridge.
Damage Description: a barge hit on the U.S. 68 Tennessee River/Kentucky Lake Eggners Ferry Bridge. The barge just scraped the pier, so no damage.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closure for few hours until inspected safe.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Comprehensive repairs including structural steel rehabilitation, replacement of hanger cables, deck replacement, drainage improvements, lighting upgrades, and repainting. Updated inspection regime, Monitoring systems installation
Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: Barge struck the protective fender around a pier. No structural damage but required immediate inspection.
Duration of Service Disruption: A four-day closure was observed at the bridge.

Cause of Incident: Bridge collapses as semi-truck hauling 4 times the weight limit crosses it
Damage Description: The bridge collapsed into the Maries River as the truck began crossing the one-lane bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Traffic was rerouted.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Regular reviews of safety barriers and emergency response protocols remain key to preventing future collisions
Cause of Incident: Possibly due to loose barges
Damage Description: One barge hit a bridge pillar on the Pomeroy side and continued floating downriver. No damage to the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary closure for few hours

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Routine Structural Monitoring, Frequent Fender/Dolphin System Evaluations
Cause of Incident: Not specified
Damage Description: A tow boat that was pushing 8 empty barges scraped a pier on the main Kentucky side of the structure. The scrape was minor.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed for few hours.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Post-strike bridge inspections, Safety reviews of tow protocols, and Enhanced river regulation and navigation controls.
Cause of Incident: The tugboat pilot's ineffective actions in countering the strong current.
Damage Description: A tugboat on the Mississippi River collided with the Luling Bridge in St. Charles Parish. The vessel was leading a train of grain barges when it crashed into the bridge, causing two of the barges to collide. So far, officials have said that the incident has not caused any injuries.

Cause of Incident: Dam failure and flood caused the damage.
Damage Description: M-30 roadway over the Tittabawassee River suffered damage to the piers, railing of the bridge, and the bridge approach was washed away due to rapid water flow.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Cause of Incident: Boat operator under the influence of alcohol
Damage Description: An incident involved the boat colliding with a railroad bridge, resulting in extensive damage to the boat.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The bridge was promptly inspected and found to be structurally sound. Only the navigation-light fixture bracing required replacement—cosmetic damage was minor.
Cause of Incident: Not specified
Damage Description: A barge carrying the iconic Coca-Cola stage from Riverbends past crashed into the Interstate 24 bridge in Marion County.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary closure

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The new bridge is longer, wider, and features improved safety measures like wider driving lanes and emergency shoulders. It also eliminates the need for piers in the river, eliminating an obstruction for river traffic.
Cause of Incident: Barge broke loose
Damage Description: A loaded rock barge hit a pier of the Cumberland River bridge. No damage but it was still replaced.

Cause of Incident: Traind derailment
Damage Description: Freight train derailment on the bridge led to fire among tank cars carrying chemicals. A portion of the century-old bridge collapsed. A prior derailment had occurred on June 26 at the same bridge.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Quick and multi-stage inspections confirmed no structural damage, only minor surface harm. Targeted repairs (grouting) were conducted to protect bridge materials against weather. Safety practices were reinforced.
Cause of Incident: High water level
Damage Description: A steel crane jutting up in the air as the barge failed to clear the underside of the steel and concrete span. The crane whip-sawed upward after it dragged along the underside of the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: There was no damage reported to the vessel or the bridge
Source / Reference: A barge carrying a crane hit the underside of Juneau's Douglas Bridge

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: After the incident, the bridge’s protective fendering was repaired, with nearly $650,000 in damage addressed to restore the bridge’s protective barrier. Mandatory Use of All Navigational Resource.
Cause of Incident: Strong current and improper planning by teh Pilot
Damage Description: The 230-foot barge Cole carrying dredge material hit the bridge’s eastside protective fendering and thereby damaging the fender.
Source / Reference: NTSB notes inadequate navigational assessment in Fla. bridge strike – Professional Mariner

Cause of Incident: The Pensacola Bay Bridge (also known as the Three Mile Bridge) suffered significant damage during Hurricane Sally in September 2020 due to a barge and crane that broke free and collided with the bridge.
Damage Description: The damage resulted in an extended closure of the bridge, impacting local businesses and commuters.
Duration of Service Disruption: The damage resulted in an extended closure of the bridge, impacting local businesses and commuters.
Estimated Repair Cost: The initial replacement project was budgeted at $430 million, but the hurricane-related damage caused by barges breaking loose and impacting the structure resulted in increased costs and delays.
Source / Reference: A portion of Pensacola's Three Mile Bridge is missing after Hurricane Sally. Here's what we know

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: DOTD installed and repaired fender lights and restored protective fender structures to meet navigational safety requirements
Cause of Incident: A corner of the bridge’s swing span was protruding outside of its protective fendering into the navigable channel after recently attempted repairs to the limit switch system that controlled the swing span’s rotation limit.
Damage Description: The towing vessels Trent Joseph and George C were towing two barges southbound in the Barataria Waterway. While passing through the open Barataria Bridge, the second barge contacted the bridge’s swing span.
Duration of Service Disruption: Unstable for few days.
Source / Reference: NTSB Determines Cause of Tow Accident with the Barataria Bridge in Louisiana

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Review or reinforcement of protective systems and navigation infrastructure; Strengthened communication protocols with vessel operators; Increased monitoring and vigilance on the river;
Cause of Incident: Captain lost control of the vessel
Damage Description: A boat capsized and collided with the Tower Bridge's center support structure. The boat operator was rescued from the water. No serious damage to the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closure for few hours

Bridge Name: Peoria and Pekin Union Railway Bridge
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Bridge remained structurally sound after inspection. The incident led to reinforced communication protocols, lookout assignments, and crew training for bridge transits.
Cause of Incident: Miscalculation by the pilot led to collision of barge onto the bridgge pier.
Damage Description: A towboat pushing two barges on the Illinois River struck a descending lift bridge near downtown Peoria, Ill., tearing off the vessel’s pilothouse.
Duration of Service Disruption: No major damage was caused, hence service wasn't disrupted.
Source / Reference: Bridge strike on Illinois River tears off towboat’s pilothouse – Professional Mariner

Bridge Name: Liberty Bridge and the Port Authority Transit Bridge.
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: While no major damage occurred in this case, structural protection enhancements (e.g., fender systems, pier guards) were evaluated for key bridge piers.
Cause of Incident: Loose barge
Damage Description: 12 barges hauling coal broke loose in the early morning hours of Monday, floating down the Mon River in the dark, and striking the Liberty Bridge and the Port Authority Transit Bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporary closure

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Evaluating the condition of protective structures (fender systems) surrounding bridge piers to verify they can absorb future impacts.
Cause of Incident: The barge did not have its equipment lowered as it crossed the bridge.
Damage Description: Barge hits Shave Bridge, minor damage reported.
Duration of Service Disruption: NMinor cosmetic damage so no disruption.

Cause of Incident: A historic bridge north of Ola was destroyed Wednesday when a semi drove over it, and the bridge collapsed. The truck was determined to weigh approximately 40 tons and the old iron bridge on Dale Bend Road had a posted weight limit of six tons.
Damage Description: The bridge partially collapsed at first, taking the semi into the river with it. By Thursday morning, the rest of the bridge had fully collapsed into the river.
Duration of Service Disruption: Following the incident, the bridge was closed and the truck and trailer remained partially submerged in the river while officials began to plan how it could be removed.
Estimated Repair Cost: The cost to repair the Dale Bend Bridge after the collapse is estimated to be over $1 million, with potential for cost reduction if a center pier is feasible.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Quick closure and thorough inspections by DOTD, railroad, and Coast Guard ensured bridge safety. Post-event measures emphasized protocol reinforcement, navigational safety, and multi-agency coordination.
Cause of Incident: High water level
Damage Description: The antenna from a passing boat struck the bridge, and the damage appears to be cosmetic.
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge was closed for few hours.

Cause of Incident: Under the influence driving
Damage Description: A fatal boat crash took the life of a person when the driver allegedly collided with a bridge. The boat struck one of the pilings of the bridge.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The Norfolk Southern Railway Bridge's fendering system was evaluated and reinforced to better absorb impacts and protect the bridge structure from future collisions.
Cause of Incident: The probable cause was the pilot's decision to navigate through a poorly aligned bridge using an unfamiliar vessel during high water and a strong current
Damage Description: Ssix loaded barges, contacted the Norfolk Southern railway bridge near Jackson, Alabama. As a result, a bridge support was shifted out of position, and the tracks above deflected.
Duration of Service Disruption: Suspended for 27 hours until further repair was made

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The bridge was inspected safe and had no damage but no preventive measures are specified.
Cause of Incident: Loose barge
Damage Description: Loose barge hit US 70 Bridge near New Johnsonville
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge was temporarily closed at Highway 70 while crews worked to determine if there was any structural damage.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Immediate actions and long-term preventive measures were implemented to protect the bridge and improve the safety of future transits such as the fender systems.
Cause of Incident: The captain lost control of the tow and the bridge too took more time to open than usual.
Damage Description: The captain lost control of the tow and the 200-foot Terral 2 hit the bridge in several places

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The new bridge design incorporated a more robust fender system to better protect the bridge from vessel impacts. The replacement bridge features a skewed 275-foot spliced girder main span to avoid conflicts with existing structures and to improve resilience against vessel collisions. Increased Clearance.
Cause of Incident: The barge was carrying two large smokestacks, which were reportedly very tall and close to the bridge as it passed underneath.
Damage Description: A barge hit the fender surrounding a set of pilings at Brooks Bridge on U.S. Highway 98 between Fort Walton Beach and Okaloosa Island. No damage.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporarily closed until investigation was done.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: While the Eads Bridge itself did not sustain damage in the 2019 incident, the event prompted a reevaluation of safety measures and navigational practices in the area to protect both infrastructure and personnel.
Cause of Incident: Possibly due to rising floodwaters.
Damage Description: A towboat struck the Eads Bridge. The Coast Guard closed a portion of the Mississippi to all vessel traffic from mile marker 179 to 184 due to extremely high water levels and fast-moving currents. No damage to the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: The USCG closed the Mississippi to vessel traffic between mile markers 179 and 184, a stretch of river that includes the Eads Bridge until the water level went down.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Unspecified
Cause of Incident: Not confirmed
Damage Description: A boat has struck a bridge piling on a train trestle belonging to Union Pacific Railroad next to the Benicia bridge.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The proposed new bridge would feature wider traffic lanes and shoulders to better accommodate farm implements and bicyclists. Additionally, it would increase the width and vertical clearance of the river navigation span, enhancing safety for river traffic and eliminating the need for around-the-clock lift operators.
Cause of Incident: High water level
Damage Description: Several barges struck a portion of the pier and a section of the bridge.  The inspection found at least two cracks in the bridge’s north truss.

Cause of Incident: The bridge collapsed after a tractor-trailer hauling beans and exceeding the weight limit drove over it
Damage Description: The collapse resulted in the truck becoming partially submerged.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The existing bridges will be replaced with a new structure that will feature more lanes and a higher vertical clearance. Construction is slated to begin in 2027 and is estimated to take five years
Cause of Incident: This incident was caused by the extreme rise and flow of water in the San Jacinto River, resulting from a historic rainfall event associated with Tropical Storm Imelda.
Damage Description: Six barges struck pier columns supporting the bridge.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: There is no indication that the NTSB conducted a formal investigation or issued post‑incident safety recommendations f
Cause of Incident: Mechanical failure
Damage Description: A barge hit the Bill Emerson Memorial Bridge. The barge was pinned against the pier side-wise, putting a large amount to the river’s pressure on the pier.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed for few days until inspected safe.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: There’s no public record of any direct remedial action taken to reinforce, inspect, or modify bridge structures post-accident
Cause of Incident: The incident occurred during a significant coastal storm event while the tugboat was attempting to recover loose work barges.
Damage Description: The semi-submerged tugboat Miss Bonnie sits in the water after alliding with the Old Bonner Bridge and is responsible for the potential maximum discharge of 6,000 gallons of diesel

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Railing replacement and structural fixes during partial closures
Cause of Incident: A combination of high water, a large amount of debris in the river, and operator error.
Duration of Service Disruption: The Ohio River was closed to traffic from Twelve Mile Island to McAlpine Lock and Dam due to the accident.

Cause of Incident: The resistance to sliding was miscalculated, and thus insufficient to prevent the connection from sliding, causing cracks in the truss concrete. As the cracking enlarged, it ultimately caused the complete disconnection of one of the truss-to-walkway connections, leading to the collapse.
Damage Description: The barge was pinned against the pier side-wise, putting a large amount to the river’s pressure on the pier.
Estimated Repair Cost: The replacement of the Florida International University pedestrian bridge, following the 2018 collapse, is estimated to cost $18.2 million for construction, with an additional $38 million for the overall project, including design and other costs.
Source / Reference: Florida International University pedestrian bridge collapse - Wikipedia
Notes: In June 2019, OSHA released its final report on the FIU bridge collapse[2] and concluded FIGG Bridge Engineers failed to recognize collapse was imminent when they inspected the bridge hours earlier. They also concluded the bridge had structural design deficiencies, severe cracks were wrongly ignored by the Engineer of Record and warranted street closure, and contract bridge design experts violated basic FDOT construction requirements.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The bridge was intentionally designed to withstand barge collisions. Engineers built it upstream and intentionally factored in vessel impact forces, traffic flow, and loads during the design phase
Cause of Incident: High current
Damage Description: Minnesota Highway 43 was struck recently by a barge going downriver on, but performed as it was designed to do
Duration of Service Disruption: It was never shut down.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: New weight restrictions to limit load stress were implemented.
Cause of Incident: A family’s drift boat colliding into a bridge pylon and capsizing.
Damage Description: Boat collided into bridge in fatal accident. No damage.
Duration of Service Disruption: No closure

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Replaced the damaged bottom chord and returned the bridge to traffic within 45 days of the incident.
Cause of Incident: Inadequate voyage planning and watch turnover between the captain and pilot, resulting in the pilot transiting beneath the bridge’s west span instead of its channel span.
Damage Description: A crane barge pushed by MV Kristin Alexis struck the westbound span, causing severe structural damage to a main load-bearing component.
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge was completely closed to vehicular traffic for 49 days while repairs were made, which resulted in significant traffic impacts.

Cause of Incident: Floodwaters rushed through the Llano River at Kingsland, causing the FM 2900 bridge to collapse and wash away.
Damage Description: The bridge connected two sides of Kingsland and the loss caused problems for its residents since what had once been a five- to 10-minute drive took about 45 minutes.
Duration of Service Disruption: Few months of detour.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Not specified
Damage Description: Minor barge hit: no substantial damage.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: A new single‑span steel plate girder bridge without intermediate supports, directly addressing landslide-caused pier vulnerabilities
Cause of Incident: One of the main support columns of the previous Pfeiffer Canyon Bridge collapsed in February from a landslide triggered by heavy rainfall.
Damage Description: The landslide displaced a support column, leading to the bridge's closure and subsequent demolition. The collapse isolated the southern portion of Big Sur, impacting residents, businesses, and tourism.
Duration of Service Disruption: The bridge was demolished in March. That cut off access to Big Sur via Highway 1 from the north.
Estimated Repair Cost: The repair of the Pfeiffer Canyon Bridge, following its collapse due to a landslide, cost $24 million. This included the demolition of the damaged bridge and the construction of a new one, completed in October 2017
Source / Reference: Big news for Big Sur: Pfeiffer Canyon Bridge rebuilt: Travel Weekly

Cause of Incident: A semi-trailer crashed into the South Eagle River Overpass.
A massive fire collapsed a section of the I-85 freeway viaduct in Atlanta, Georgia, stranding motorists for miles during rush hour traffic.
Damage Description: Excessive heat had caused the loss of pretension of the bridge reinforcement bars, and the bridge spans exhibited delamination and cracking throughout the bottom flanges.
Duration of Service Disruption: I-85 was closed to traffic for 43 days between its split with I-75 and the interchange with State Route 400 (SR 400) — approximately two miles (3 km).

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Boating speed limits and life jacket usage—were reinforced to protect both navigational and road users.
Cause of Incident: Not known
Damage Description: A woman was killed after her boat rammed into one of the pylons under the Interstate 205 Bridge Monday night. The boat, an 18-20 foot pleasure craft of some kind, sank after hitting the pylon.
Source / Reference: Woman killed when boat strikes Interstate 205 Bridge - The Columbianks-below-interstate-205-bridge/

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: MnDOT already enforces a strict lift schedule, personnel monitoring marine radios, and a protocol for boaters to call 24 hours in advance outside normal seasons
Damage Description: The upper portion of a 37-foot boat was sheared off when it hit the bridge.The upper portion of a 37-foot boat was sheared off when it hit the bridge.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed until inspected safe.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Fender and dock repairs; enhanced navigation caution messages
Cause of Incident: High current
Damage Description: Great Lakes freighter backing out of the Fox River struck a moored powerboat and ran into a drawbridge in downtown Green Bay. A bridge gangway on the fendering and docks along the river also were damaged.
Duration of Service Disruption: 4 hours closure

Cause of Incident: The storm caused severe erosion and scouring around the bridge's support pilings, leading to concerns about its stability and potential collapse.
Damage Description: The pilings holding up the bridge washed out.
Duration of Service Disruption: The Army Corps of Engineers made temporary repairs to stabilize the bridge before a new one would ultimately replace it.

Bridge Name: St. Paul Union Pacific Rail Swing Bridge
Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The NTSB recommended that bridge owners assess and upgrade fendering systems to better withstand impacts from vessels, reducing the risk of structural damage and ensuring continued safe operation of the bridge.
Cause of Incident: Inexperienced pilot who incorrectly positioned the tow prior to maneuvering through a turn with a following current when approaching the bridge span.
Damage Description: The lead barge on the port side struck a fixed pier of the swing bridge.

Cause of Incident: The tractor hit the bridge, causing it to collapse. The driver of the tractor told deputies that he didn't realize his attachment was wider than the bridge when he tried to cross.
Damage Description: A tractor tried to pass over Holliday Bridge, north of Zionsville. The bridge collapsed into a pile of twisted metal as a tractor was crossing the span.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Enhanced Navigational Training and Procedures, Improved Safety Management Systems (SMS), Enhanced Bridge and Waterway Monitoring
Cause of Incident: High current and swollen Mississippi River caused barges to break loose.
Damage Description: A towboat pushing barges struck a pier of the Helena Highway Bridge, sending four barges traveling free
Duration of Service Disruption: No damage was recorded.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Completed repairs on damaged gear teeth and steel girders caused during a barge accident June 4.
Cause of Incident: Unknown
Damage Description: A barge traveling the Intracoastal Waterway in Chesapeake, Va. struck the Centerville Turnpike Bridge early Saturday morning, damaging the bridge and shutting down traffic. According to Chesapeake Roads, the bridge became stuck in the open position because of damage suffered in the strike.
Duration of Service Disruption: 6 months closure. The Centerville Turnpike Bridge underwent a major reconstruction project that wrapped up in February 2020.

Cause of Incident: The collapse occurred when a semi-truck hauling a boom lift collided with the bridge, causing the northbound lanes to fall onto Northwest Expressway.
Damage Description: The bridge collapsed in 2016 after a truck carrying construction equipment hit it and destroyed three beams. While the collapse was significant, fortunately, no injuries were reported. While the collapse was significant, fortunately, no injuries were reported.
Duration of Service Disruption: City officials estimated that the repair work, which involved replacing damaged beams and the bridge deck, would take two to three months.
Estimated Repair Cost: The cost to repair the May Avenue bridge after the 2016 collapse was $575,823.28.
Source / Reference: City seeks input on May Avenue bridge project after 2016 collapse

Bridge Name: Hopple Street Overpass over I-75 Southbound
Cause of Incident: The Hopple Street exit ramp collapsed onto I-75 S on January 19, 2015 during demolition at approximately 10:30 PM.
Damage Description: As the center span collapsed, a semi truck crashed into the debris, injuring the driver. Demolition had been halted earlier in the week due to concerns about the upward deflection of some steel girders and inadequate remedial measures were put in place. One foreman was killed and the excavator operator was injured.
Duration of Service Disruption: The collapse occurred during demolition work, specifically when concrete was being removed from the bridge deck. The incident led to the closure of I-75 Southbound and prompted investigations into the cause of the collapse.
Estimated Repair Cost: The cost to repair the Hopple Street Overpass over I-75 Southbound, following the collapse of an exit ramp during construction, was $91.6 million.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Not specified
Cause of Incident: High winds from the blizzard Juno
Damage Description: One of the four industrial lines that anchor the barge became unstrapped and caused the barge to move during low tide. It struck one of the bridge’s eastern piers outside the navigation channel. No damage.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: Bridge owners reviewed and upgraded fendering systems to better absorb vessel impacts and reduce risk of structural damage during accidental collisions.
Cause of Incident: Strong current
Damage Description: A barge sank Saturday on the Mississippi River after the towboat that was guiding it struck a railroad bridge. Bridge was not damaged.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: The damaged fender system, which serves as a protective barrier for the bridge piers, was repaired to restore its functionality and protect the bridge from future maritime impacts.
Cause of Incident: The barge struck a "fender system" around a piling on the south side of the span.
Damage Description: The fender system is basically a wood structure with steel beams around the piling and (the barge) knocked out about 60 foot of it, so it was a pretty good impact on that.
Duration of Service Disruption: No damage was recorded but the toll bridge was closed early.

Cause of Incident: The Tex Wash Bridge on Interstate 10 (I-10) in Riverside County, California, collapsed due to a severe rainstorm. The collapse, which occurred during an intense rainstorm, caused the closure of I-10 between Coachella and Blythe, impacting traffic between California and Arizona.
Damage Description: The storm was extremely rare and powerful, but its destructive force was magnified by critical flaws in the design of the bridge, according to an engineering expert's new study of the bridge failure.
Duration of Service Disruption: A detour was established, and the bridge was replaced using precast concrete and an accelerated bridge construction strategy.
Estimated Repair Cost: The I-10 "Tex Wash" overpass collapse repair cost was $5 million. This cost covered the demolition of the damaged eastbound span and the construction of a new 105-foot replacement bridge using Accelerated Bridge Construction (ABC) methods.
Source / Reference: Doomed to Fail: The fatal flaws of the Tex Wash Bridge

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: NCDOT began repairs to the damaged fender system on August 17, 2015. The work was scheduled to continue until October 23, 2015, with minimal disruptions to vehicular traffic.
Cause of Incident: A combination of wind, current, and over-correction by the boat operator may have led to the accident.
Damage Description: A tug boat pushing a barge ran into the structure.  A tug boat pushing a barge ran into the structure.

Cause of Incident: The Bob White Covered Bridge in Patrick County, Virginia, was destroyed by severe flooding in September 2015. The 80-foot bridge, built in 1921, was washed away entirely, leaving only the bridge supports remaining.
Damage Description: The bridge washed away and was destroyed in major flooding on September 29, 2015

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: While the bridge structure remained undamaged, the fender system sustained damage. FDOT initiated repairs to the fender system to restore its protective function and prevent future incidents.
Cause of Incident: The crane on the barge was too high and struck the bridge girders on both the eastbound and westbound spans, causing some concrete to break off and fall into the Indian River. The
Damage Description: The barge struck the bridge that spans over the Indian River. An inspection of the bridge determined the eastbound side, which is concrete, had scraping, with some small portions of concrete coming loose.
Duration of Service Disruption: Temporarily closed.

Cause of Incident: A 5- acre fire spread to the Oxbow Bridge which collapsed into the Colorado River.
Damage Description: The bridge has some remains left in the Colorado River, but it's completely impassible.

Cause of Incident: A semitruck hit the White River Bridge causing the several panels in the bridge to distort.
Damage Description: The horizontal and vertical compents of the bridge were damaged on all seven panels.

Confirmed Post-Incident Safety Actions: None specified.
Cause of Incident: Deposit from a past volcanic eruption led to debris flowing and washing out Spirit Lake Outlet Bridge.
Damage Description: The bridge was washed out and covered with mud, rock, ice, and water.
Duration of Service Disruption: Closed until completed reconstruction.
